title: Marie Curie: A Life of Discovery
summary: Marie Curie followed her curiosity from a small town in Poland to world-changing discoveries about invisible energy called radioactivity.
imageAlt: Stylized illustration of a glowing chemistry flask representing Marie Curie's laboratory.
author: Jacob Sutanto
body: Marie Curie, born Maria Sklodowska in Warsaw, Poland, loved solving puzzles more than anything. She memorized constellations, practiced math riddles with her father, and spent rainy afternoons taking apart clocks just to see how the gears fit together again.

In Poland the government closed advanced schools to girls, so Maria joined a secret evening class where teachers risked arrest to share science. To earn money for train fare to Paris, she worked as a tutor and saved every coin.

Paris was cold and crowded, yet thrilling. Maria—who now called herself Marie—studied at the Sorbonne, attending chemistry and physics lectures by day and copying notes late into the night until she ranked first in her class.

In a lab full of dusty instruments, Marie met another curious scientist named Pierre Curie. They married and became partners who tested crystals and mysterious minerals that glowed faintly in the dark. Marie wondered if the glow meant the atoms inside those rocks were releasing invisible energy.

To find out, Marie crushed tons of a heavy ore called pitchblende, stirring boiling pots for hours and separating one grain at a time. Her experiments proved the rocks gave off their own energy, so she named the phenomenon radioactivity and discovered two new elements: polonium, honoring her homeland, and radium, which shone with a pale blue light.

The Curies' discoveries changed medicine and science. Laboratories used radium to study atoms, and doctors learned to aim the energy at tumors. Marie became the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and later earned a second for her ongoing experiments.

When World War I erupted, Marie refused to leave her knowledge in the laboratory. She designed small X-ray vehicles nicknamed "Little Curies" and trained nurses to drive them. Rolling over muddy roads, she used the machines to spot broken bones so surgeons could help soldiers faster.

After the war, Marie opened research institutes in Paris and Warsaw and offered scholarships to young scientists who lacked money, just as she once had. Her story shows that brave questions, steady effort, and a generous heart can brighten the world for everyone.

questions.prompt: Which challenge pushed Marie Curie to leave Poland?
options: Girls were not allowed in the science classes she wanted to take.
She could not find any puzzles to solve at home.
Her family asked her to become a baker instead.
questions.explanation: Marie moved to Paris because universities near her home would not let women study advanced science.

questions.prompt: Why did Marie study how rocks give off energy?
options: She wanted to decorate her lab with glowing stones.
She was curious about invisible energy that could change the world.
She hoped to build a new clock for her village.
questions.explanation: Her curiosity about invisible energy guided her discoveries about radioactivity.

questions.prompt: Marie saved money and moved to the city of ____ to keep learning science.
questions.explanation: She traveled to Paris so she could attend the Sorbonne.

options: A kind of music Marie played while she worked
Energy that some materials give off all by themselves
A machine that takes pictures of bones
questions.explanation: Radioactivity is energy that certain elements release without needing light.

questions.prompt: Place these events from Marie Curie's life in order.
sequence: Marie explored puzzles and tools as a child in Poland
She studied at the Sorbonne in Paris
Marie and Pierre discovered polonium and radium
She drove X-ray vans to help soldiers during the war
questions.explanation: Marie first loved science as a child, then studied in Paris, made discoveries, and later brought X-rays to the battlefield.

questions.prompt: During World War I, Marie drove a special van that carried ____ machines.
questions.explanation: She brought X-ray machines so doctors could see broken bones quickly.

questions.prompt: How did Marie's discoveries help doctors?
options: They taught doctors how to bake bread for patients.
They allowed doctors to see inside bodies with X-rays.
They helped doctors fly airplanes more safely.
questions.explanation: Her careful experiments made medical X-rays possible for hospitals and soldiers.

questions.prompt: Explain how Marie Curie's curiosity shaped her scientific journey.
acceptableAnswers: Her curiosity pushed her to keep asking questions, study in Paris, and make discoveries about radioactivity.
Because she was curious, she studied hard, explored radioactivity, and helped invent new science tools.
questions.explanation: Marie kept following questions, which led her to the Sorbonne, new elements, and medical inventions.

questions.prompt: Why is Marie Curie's story inspiring to readers?
options: She won awards without working hard.
She turned brave questions into discoveries that helped the world.
She traveled only so she could sightsee in new cities.
questions.explanation: Marie kept learning and used her science to help others, which shows courage and care.
